instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2914: What is 820-2914? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U5701: What is U5701? this is the keyboard controller chip that takes the keyboard and trackpad input and turns it into a USB device signal for the machine to process. If replacing a keyboard doesnâ€™t fix an issue with keys not typing, check all traces between keyboard connector and this IC. This chip has programming so it must be replaced from a similar, ideally identical board. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PM_SLP_S5L: What is PM_SLP_S5L? This is a typo of PM_SLP_S5_L When you see PM_SLP_S5L, assume they meant to type PM_SLP_S5_L.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No keyboard and trackpad
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> is arriving with only 2.4v at <RESISTOR>R5704</RESISTOR>, right before <CHIP>U5701</CHIP>. Pulled off <CHIP>U5701</CHIP>, all caps, <CHIP>U5750</CHIP>, <CHIP>U5755</CHIP> but still no getting 3.3v. <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5L</SIGNAL> is measuring 3.3v but I think what is biting me here is that I only have boardview for revision A of this board. <SIGNAL>P3V3_S4_EN</SIGNAL> is not present but i don't get it as it is made by <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5L</SIGNAL> which measured ok.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No keyboard and trackpad
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R7916</RESISTOR> is marked as "no stuff" on the diagram, but is it really not on the board? I see no other way for <SIGNAL>P3V3_S4_EN</SIGNAL> to be connected...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No keyboard and trackpad
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R7916</RESISTOR> is not on the board. This schematic is clearly missing something. You think is ok to bridge <RESISTOR>R7916</RESISTOR>? May a board internal trace got burned and developed resistance, as <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> arrives with 2.4v at the keyboard and trackpad HUB?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No keyboard and trackpad
threads.message: Looking at a few other diagrams it may be connected to <SIGNAL>SMC_S4_WAKESRC_EN</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No keyboard and trackpad
threads.message: Confirmed. Measured below 3.3v on <SIGNAL>SMC_S4_WAKESRC_EN</SIGNAL> too. As it is created by the SMC, can I assume it's a bad SMC case? If that is correct, woudn't be easier to make a bridge?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No keyboard and trackpad
threads.message: I would more suspect  something pulling it low, so <TRANSISTOR>Q7812</TRANSISTOR> should first be replaced.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No keyboard and trackpad
threads.message: Measuring resistance between SMC pin 10 probe point and <CHIP>U9480</CHIP> I get something in the order of mega ohm. Concluded that the board trace got fucked, making a bridge between those 2 points then.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No keyboard and trackpad
threads.message: After bridging I got 2,8v at the cap before <CHIP>U5701</CHIP>. Then removed <CHIP>U5701</CHIP> and got 3,17v. Is that enough?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No keyboard and trackpad
threads.message: What cap?...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No keyboard and trackpad
threads.message: Measuring 3.17v at <CAPACITOR>C5701</CAPACITOR> with <CHIP>U5701</CHIP> pulled off.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No keyboard and trackpad
threads.message:
No that is no good of course. You removed all the load on that rail now that <CHIP>U5701</CHIP> is gone. With the load of <CHIP>U5701</CHIP> there should be 3.3V. Is enable now coming to <TRANSISTOR>Q7812</TRANSISTOR>? Is pin3 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7810</TRANSISTOR> being pulled down?
Why of why did you pull off <CHIP>U5701</CHIP>, another variable now to the problems.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No keyboard and trackpad
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 28835"]No that is no good of course. You removed all the load on that rail now that <CHIP>U5701</CHIP> is gone. With the load of <CHIP>U5701</CHIP> there should be 3.3V. Is enable now coming to <TRANSISTOR>Q7812</TRANSISTOR>? Is pin3 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7810</TRANSISTOR> being pulled down?
Why of why did you pull off <CHIP>U5701</CHIP>, another variable now to the problems.[/QUOTE]

Removed becouse it was still measuring low. Measured resistance from <SIGNAL>SMC_S4_WAKESRC_EN</SIGNAL> to <SIGNAL>P3V3_S4_EN</SIGNAL> on <CAPACITOR>C5701</CAPACITOR> and get 10k. Maybe another trace got burn? It feels like the schematics are incomplete on this one...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No keyboard and trackpad
threads.message:
Let me rephrase, voltage on pin 2 <TRANSISTOR>Q7812</TRANSISTOR> and pin 3 <TRANSISTOR>Q7810</TRANSISTOR>?
Put back <CHIP>U5701</CHIP> also.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No keyboard and trackpad
threads.message:
With <CHIP>U5701</CHIP>:

<TRANSISTOR>Q7812</TRANSISTOR> pin 2: 3.33v
<TRANSISTOR>Q7810</TRANSISTOR> pin 3: 0v
<CHIP>U5701</CHIP> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4_PSOC</SIGNAL> probe point: Voltage all around and never above 2.1v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No keyboard and trackpad
threads.message: Still not figured whats pulling this voltage down.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No keyboard and trackpad
threads.message: Voltage before(pin7,4) <TRANSISTOR>Q7810</TRANSISTOR> and after(pin 1)? If the voltage drop is over <TRANSISTOR>Q7810</TRANSISTOR> then measure resistance to GND on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4_PSOC</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No keyboard and trackpad
threads.message: Both pins on <TRANSISTOR>Q7810</TRANSISTOR> measured 3,33v. Can we assume is the board inner connection that got burned? I'm just about to bridge it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No keyboard and trackpad
threads.message: Seems like it, why not beep it out with the meter?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No keyboard and trackpad
threads.message: I measured current draw with my power supply at <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4_PSOC</SIGNAL> and it was 0.0024 amps. So no short on this line. Then I bridged it which bring keyboard back to live. But still no trackpad, which I swapped with a known good and still no dice. 3.3v arriving at keyboard connector. Safe to say it's time to replace <CHIP>U5701</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No keyboard and trackpad
threads.message: Issue is now between trackpad connector and <CHIP>U5701</CHIP>. Do a diode mode on all the connector pins and compare. But yeah <CHIP>U5701</CHIP> is easily killed, that is why you never pull it unless 100% sure it's dead.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No keyboard and trackpad
threads.message: Will do diode mode, happen to have a good board here to compare. Is really <CHIP>U5701</CHIP> a sissy? I pulled it off and back like 3 times already...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No keyboard and trackpad
threads.message: Yes <CHIP>U5701</CHIP> is a sissy that is why I was sad that you pulled it off to begin with.
